prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA, for leaving my fiance of 7 years.
My fiance and I have been together for 7 years now and have an almost 6 year old son together.

Almost 3 years ago now we had broken up for about a month. During this time he began to talk to a girl that he's known for most of his life. We got back together, and I expected him to break off all contact with her. Which I thought was understandable.

2 weeks in and he still has her on all social media including snapchat. We fought and fought over it and he eventually deleted her. Or so I thought.

Last October, we had been growing rather distant and I took it upon myself to snoop through his phone.

And there she is. She had blocked me on social media so that I couldn't see them following each other. He had literally liked every single one of her pictures, not any of mine during the same time period to be clear, and she liked his as well. Including a picture of his Snapchat code asking people to add him.

I confront him. He becomes angry and defensive but swears hell get rid of her.

About a month later I decide to check again. And she's still there. So I told him I was leaving him.

He left for about 3 days. And we eventually talked things through and he again swore to delete her and block her for good.

3 weeks ago, I saw that he had liked pictures of the girl's sister on Instagram. He says he had remembered liking them from a long time ago and had been trying to unlike them so I would never find them and in doing so accidentally re liked the pictures, and I believed him.

Last night. He has both the girl AND her sister unblocked AGAIN on social media. Meaning he went out of his way to go through his settings, get to privacy, open his list of blocked users and unblocked those two in particular.

WIBTA for ending a 7 year relationship with the father of my son because he can't seem to let go of some other girl? Even though the only thing I really have evidence of is them staying in contact, not actually cheating?

I'm at a complete loss.
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the given situation is in the wrong for leaving their fiancé after 7 years. The key points here are the ongoing issues with the fiancé's contact with another girl, despite the author's requests.

First, the relationship has been going on for a long time, and they have a child together. The author took the initiative to check the fiancé's phone after feeling distant, which led to the discovery of interactions with this girl. The fiancé had previously deleted her, but she came back, and now even the sister is involved. The author confronted the fiancé multiple times, each time leading to promises to delete and block, but those promises weren't kept. 

The main question is whether the author is in the wrong for ending the relationship based on evidence of continued contact, even without proven cheating. The author's actions—snooping and then leaving—might be seen as a last resort after repeated breaches of trust. The fiancé's behavior shows a pattern of not respecting the author's boundaries, which is a significant issue in a long-term relationship. 

On one hand, some might argue that the author overstepped by snooping, but in the context of a serious relationship with a child, trust and commitment are crucial. The fiancé's inability to cut off contact could indicate emotional unavailability or lack of commitment, which is a valid reason to end the relationship. 

On the other hand, the fiancé claims he was trying to unlike the posts but made a mistake. However, the pattern is consistent: each time the author finds evidence, the fiancé promises to stop, but it happens again. The author is justified in feeling that there's no genuine effort to address the issue. 

Considering the long-term nature and the presence of a child, the author's decision to end the relationship due to repeated unfaithfulness (even if not physical cheating) might be seen as necessary for their own well-being and the integrity of the relationship. So the answer is B.
